This week's translation was an agreement of a product with a denomination of origin. Do you know what this means? ü§î üëâ According to the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO), geographical indication is a sign used on products that have a specific geographical origin and possess qualities or a reputation that are due to that origin. üëâ An appellation or denomination of origin is a special kind of geographical indication generally consisting of a geographical name or a traditional designation used on products that have a specific quality or characteristics that are essentially due to the geographical environment in which they are produced. Usually, it refers to a locality, city, country, or region where the product has been collected, transformed, or manufactured. They both protect the product name from misuse or imitation. üíØ üåè The names of certain beverages, such as Tequila, Champagne, or Pisco are typical examples of these specialized brands, which are recognized worldwide for their particular characteristics. üá¶üá∑ In Argentina, we can mention YERBA MATE, SALAME DE TANDIL, and CHIVITO CRIOLLO DEL NORTE NEUQUINO as denominations of origin. üßâüòäüîñüòã

Yesterday we had a very insightful panel discussion in the main auditorium of Semana Internacional do Caf√© in #MinasGerais, #Brazil. First, Marcos Jank gave us a very interesting overview of Brazil¬¥s path for commodity success over the last 20 years. Coffee is just one of the many commodities where Brazil¬¥s impressive productivity growth (both in total factor productivity and on yields per hectare, averaging 2,57% per year over the last 45 years) has made this country one of the main sources of calories for the whole world. Among the challenges for the future, professor Jank highlighted the need to improve Brazil¬¥s image as a source through, among others, added value programs and differentiation in a similar way that Colombian coffee or Australian beef has done. Then Priscilla Lins from Sebrae-MG presented her views on the role specific origins can address this challenge, adapting the differentiation narrative to specific market and consumer requirements prevalent in the modern world. Lastly, I had the opportunity to share some aspects of the Colombian coffee experience and the road ahead of documenting differentiation through deeper product knowledge, which is an integral part of any #geographicalindications project. Looking forward to my next trip to Minas Gerais, hopefully in the near future.

At the 15th edition of the Cocoa and Chocolate Fair in Lima (Peru), Switzerland was the partner country, chosen for its tradition and importance in the global chocolate industry. For this reason, it organised an important delegation with various activities with companies, experts and SMEs, led by the Swiss Embassy and #SECO. In addition, the Swiss Chamber of Commerce organised the Swiss Pavilion for visitors. A delegation of Swiss experts was in Lima to participate in conferences, field visits, business meetings, exhibitions, seminars and tastings for buyers and producers. These activities included the participation of #SIPPO with #Swisscontact and other Swiss cooperation partners such as SECO, #SWISSCO, the Swiss Chamber of Commerce, Helvetas, etc. The Swiss delegation was led by the Swiss Ambassador to Peru. SIPPO was present to support its partners, #PROMPERU and #Agromercado (formerly SSE), with its international consultant, Jeroen (Jerome) Kruft, on cocoa markets and trends, and its local expert, Vilsic Bocangel who developed a sensory map and offered a tasting of Peruvian chocolates to buyers attending the business roundtable organised by Promperu and other sessions for exhibitors organised by Agromercado_MIDAGRI. This roundtable addressed key questions about chocolate production: ‚ñ∂ How do European chocolate manufacturers address business sustainability? ‚è© Which sustainable cocoa and chocolate production practices have proven to be the most effective? ‚û° How are new regulations affecting the cocoa and chocolate supply chain? The cocoa tasting made the business roundtable more effective and, according to Promperu, has a projected turnover of 7.2 million dollars over the next 12 months. ‚èπ As a next step, SIPPO has developed a set of strategic recommendations for the positioning of the event, that will be delivered by SECO to the Peruvian association of cocoa producers #APPCACAO, the leader of the Cocoa and Chocolate Show.

The social and economic impact and the boom of specialty coffee production in coffee growing communities and in Colombia. The production of specialty coffee in Colombia has experienced significant growth in recent years, driven by the growing world demand and the recognition of the exceptional quality of Colombian coffee. Samaria Coffe plays an active role in the development of local coffee communities and in strengthening the specialty coffee sector in the country. One of our main objectives is to generate a positive social and economic impact in the communities where we operate. To achieve this, we focus on improving the living conditions of farmers and their families through fair commercial practices, such as the payment of decent wages and the promotion of gender equity. We also promote training and education on issues related to sustainability, quality and innovation. The boom in specialty coffee production in Colombia has multiple benefits for the country, including strengthening Colombia's reputation as a producer of high quality coffees, increasing foreign investment and promoting coffee-related tourism. At Samaria Coffe, we are proud to be part of this movement and are committed to continue playing an active role in the growth and consolidation of the specialty coffee industry in Colombia. #FamilySelection #SamariaCoffee #TraditionCoffee #OriginCoffee #Samaria90Years #SpecialtyCoffee

üîé Continuing our journey through the history of coffee in Brazil, we have reached a crucial moment. For a long time, coffee was cultivated in the country solely for domestic consumption, but in 1776, an important milestone occurred: the first seeds were planted in the Southeast region, specifically in Rio de Janeiro, which brought more prominence to the product. However, it was in the 19th century that things really began to change. Coffee consumption was on the rise, and Brazilian producers saw a unique opportunity amidst the gold crisis in Portugal and the intense competition for sugar. üí∞ Coffee was the obvious choice, and its production quickly began to grow. üåç With increasing demand, attractive prices, and lower costs, coffee soon became Brazil's main export product. The country's economy revolved around coffee plantations, especially between the regions of Rio de Janeiro and S√£o Paulo. Coffee became the backbone of the Brazilian economy, but the challenges faced deeply shaped its trajectory. What else is yet to come? üå± Keep following our posts to discover how coffee has endured tough times and become the driving force of a nation. ‚òï #BrazilianCoffeeHistory #AtlanticaCoffee #CoffeeHistory #BrazilianCoffees #CoffeeInBrazil
